title: Richard W. Day (educator)
text:
Richard Ward Day (August 14, 1916 – July 3, 1978) was an American educator and the 10th <a href="List%20of%20Phillips%20Exeter%20Academy%20Principals">principal</a> of <a href="Phillips%20Exeter%20Academy">Phillips Exeter Academy</a>.
Richard W. Day was born in <a href="Boston">Boston</a>, <a href="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a> on August 14, 1916, to Hilbert Francis Day and Elizabeth V. H. Richards. He attended <a href="Shady%20Hill%20School">Shady Hill School</a> in <a href="Cambridge%2C%20Massachusetts">Cambridge, Massachusetts</a>, and <a href="Belmont%20Hill%20School">Belmont Hill School</a> in <a href="Belmont%2C%20Massachusetts">Belmont, Massachusetts</a>, and was educated at <a href="Yale%20University">Yale University</a>, where he graduated in 1938. During World War II, Day was inducted into the <a href="U.S.%20Army">U.S. Army</a> in March 1942 and was commissioned in November; he served for a time in the S2 section of the 515th Parachute Infantry Regiment and was assigned as an aide-de-camp to General <a href="Ridgely%20Gaither">Gaither</a> in December 1943. He was promoted to <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> and served with <a href="101st%20Airborne%20Division">101st Airborne Division</a> in the Pacific theater as a paratrooper. After the war, he attended <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a>, where he earned his doctorate in 1950. From 1964 to 1973, he served as the principal at Exeter. He was appointed in 1963; however, due to other commitments he was unable to assume his position until the following year. William Earnest Gillespie instead served as interim principal. Under him, the <a href="Phillips%20Exeter%20Academy%20Library">Class of 1945 Library</a>, designed by <a href="Louis%20Kahn">Louis Kahn</a>, was commissioned and built. The academy also became coeducational under Day in 1970. Following his time at Exeter, he served as the principal of <a href="Montclair%20Kimberley%20Academy">Montclair Kimberley Academy</a>. Across his life, he had taught at several institutions, including <a href="Germantown%20Academy">Germantown Academy</a>, <a href="Choate%20Rosemary%20Hall">Choate Rosemary Hall</a>, and <a href="St.%20Paul%27s%20School%20%28New%20Hampshire%29">St. Paul's School</a> in New Hampshire. He also was a trustee of the <a href="College%20Entrance%20Examination%20Board">College Entrance Examination Board</a>, <a href="Saddle%20River%20Country%20Day%20School">Saddle River Country Day School</a> and <a href="Mount%20Saint%20Dominic%20Academy">Mount Saint Dominic Academy</a>.
He was married to Katharine MacAusland, with whom he had two sons, Richard W. Day Jr. and Andrew MacA. Day, and a daughter, Lydia Day Hart. He died on July 3, 1978, at the age of 61, in <a href="Montclair%2C%20New%20Jersey">Montclair</a>, <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>, and was buried in <a href="Mayflower%20Cemetery">Mayflower Cemetery</a> in <a href="Duxbury%2C%20Massachusetts">Duxbury</a>, Massachusetts.
